Synthesis of bifunctional catalysts is very important for the hydrogenation of biomass to advanced biofuels, but its efficient regulation is difficult. In this work, a tunable bifunctional Ru/LaQS catalyst with Lewis acid and metal hydrogenation sites was prepared by stable MOFs (LaQS) supported ultrafine Ru nanoparticles (NPs). When the optimal Ru2/LaQS catalyst catalyzed bio-based ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL), the EL conversion and GVL selectivity reached 99.9% under mild conditions of 100 °C. The excellent catalytic performance is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs with only 1.60 nm generated by metal-support interaction, which is proved by experimental characterization and theoretical calculation. Moreover, the electron density of hydrogenation active site Ru0 and the content of acidic site Ru3+ can be modulated by Ru loading. Among them, the activation of H2 was promoted by the high electron density of Ru0 generated through metal-support electronic interactions. The enhanced medium-strong acidic site Ru3+ not only improved the activation of EL, but also promoted the intramolecular dealcoholization of the intermediate to GVL. The synergistic catalytic mechanism of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs was speculated. The excellent stability was mainly attributed to the metal-support interaction stabilizing the ultrafine Ru NPs, which prevents the agglomeration and loss of Ru NPs during cycling. This work provides an in-depth understanding of the bifunctional catalytic mechanism, which is of guiding significance for the design and preparation of MOFs-based catalysts for biomass hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract An adjustable bifunctional Ru/LaQS catalyst with Lewis acid and metal hydrogenation activity was prepared by stable MOF (LaQS) supported ultrafine Ru nanoparticles. The excellent catalytic performance of ethyl acetylpropionate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of Ru0-Ru3+ on Ru NPs with only 1.60 nm generated by metal-support interaction. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Ultrafine Ru NPs Support-metal interaction Ru0-Ru3+ synergistic catalysis Ethyl levulinateγ-valerolactone Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cheap and renewable biomass, as a precursor for the replacement of fossil energy, has attracted wide attention[1–4]. Among them, γ-valerolactone (GVL), which can be used as a renewable biofuel, has been widely studied because of its unique fuel characteristics[5]. Levulinic acid (LA) is listed as one of the twelve most important biomass platform molecules by the U.S. Department of Energy[6–8]. Levulinic acid is an important raw material for the synthesis of GVL, especially its esters have more advantages[9–11]. Compared with LA, ethyl levulinate (EL) is not acidic and has a relatively low boiling point, which is more advantageous to the stability of the catalyst and the corrosion resistance of the reaction vessel. Moreover, the catalytic conditions for the preparation of GVL by EL are milder and more environmentally friendly[12]. So, catalyzing EL to GVL is an environmentally friendly production route, but it still faces great challenges. The catalytic process of EL to GVL is divided into two steps: hydrogenation reduction and intramolecular dealcoholization, which are influenced by metal active sites and Lewis acid sites respectively[13,14]. Among them, the hydrogenation step depends on the activity of the metal catalyst, and the dehydration ring-closing step depends on the acidic site of the catalyst[15–17]. Therefore, the key to efficiently convert EL to GVL is the synergistic effect of hydrogenation active sites and Lewis acid sites in bifunctional regulatory catalysts. Currently, supported single-metal catalysts, especially noble-metal catalysts (Pt, Pd, Ru, etc.) have shown excellent performance in the hydrogenation of biomass platform compounds[18–21]. Among them, Ru has a lower barrier for CO than Pt and Pd[22]. Meanwhile, the supported nano-Ru catalyst has excellent activation ability for H2 molecules and CO bonds in LA and EL[23–26]. Gao et al. investigated the impact of different crystal types of CeO2-supported Ru on the catalytic hydrogenation of EL to GVL, and achieved complete conversion of EL with a GVL selectivity of 54.8% under conditions of 100 °C and 4 MPa H2 [23]. Shen et al. prepared CNT-Ru-1 catalyst by loading N-heterocyclic ruthenium carbon (NHC-Ru) on multi-wall carbon nanotubes (CNT), resulting in a 99% of the EL conversion and GVL yield of 93%, but a by-product of levulinic acid methyl ester[24]. Therefore, it is very necessary to develop efficient Ru-based catalysts under mild conditions. The metal particle size of supported metal catalysts will significantly affect the hydrogenation performance[27–29], especially the metal clusters with the size less than 2 nm[30,31]. Zhan et al. synthesized a Ru-based supported catalyst with the minimum Ru metal size (2.0 nm), which provided more active sites and achieved the highest yield of cyclohexanol in phenol hydrogenation[32]. Ning Yan et al. catalyzed the hydrogenation of aromatic plastic waste into aromatic hydrocarbons using Ru/Nb2O5 catalysts, attributing its exceptional performance to the small-sized Ru atoms on Nb2O5 that hindered adsorption and hydrogenation of aromatic rings[33]. Consequently, current research on hydrogenation catalysts focuses on preparing ultrafine metal particle catalysts with high activity and selectivity. With the deepening of research in recent years, it is found that the interaction between metal and support in supported catalysts can not only adjust the size of metal particles, but also effectively regulate the hydrogenation performance of the catalyst through electronic effect[34]. The literature has demonstrated that the acidity modulation of the catalyst surface can enhance the hydrogenation performance[35–39]. Literature shows that in the preparation process from LA to GVL, whether the intermediate HPA can be effectively converted into GVL under mild conditions mainly depends on Lewis acid sites[40,41]. Moreover, the intramolecular dehydration process of HPA is usually considered the rate-determining step[1]. The choice of support also has a great influence on the catalytic performance of supported Ru nanocatalysts in hydrogenation reactions[42]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) materials are characterized by their large specific surface area and high porosity. The study of metal particles supported on stable MOFs support has attracted a lot of attention in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Moreover, the interaction between MOFs support and metal nanoparticles (NPs) can not only disperse metal particles into small sizes, but also regulate the electronic effect between MOFs and metal NPs, so as to improve the catalytic performance[43–46]. Therefore, it is very necessary to develop MOFs-supported bifunctional Ru-based catalysts with Lewis acid and metal hydrogenation sites. In this work, noble metal Ru with excellent hydrogenation performance and low price was selected as the active component, and a bifunctional Ru/MOF catalyst with both hydrogenation sites and Lewis acid sites was designed, which can efficiently catalyze the conversion of EL to GVL under mild conditions. Highly dispersed ultrafine Ru NPs are generated by metal-support interaction, and electron-rich hydrogenation sites (Ru0) and enhanced Lewis acid sites (Ru3+) can be obtained by adjusting the loading of metal Ru. The influence of synergistic catalysis of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs was studied by correlation characterization and theoretical calculation system, and the synergistic catalysis mechanism was also speculated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials LaCl3·xH2O (99.0%) and Ethyl levulinate (99.0%) were purchased from Adamas Reagent Co. RuCl3·xH2O and 8-Hydroxyquinoline-5-sulfonic Acid. Monohydrate was purchased from TCI (Shanghai). Development Co. isopropanol (99.7%), ethanol (99.7%), Dichloromethane(99.7%), Ethylenediamine (99.7%), N,N-Dimethylformamide (99.7%) and NaBH4 (99.7%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source at 50 W, 15 KV on a PHI5000 Versaprobe II scanning XPS microprobe system. XPS spectra were fitted on the software MultiPak to analyze all elemental compositions and chemical species in the samples, with binding energy based on a C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were recorded at 40 kV and 40 mA on a Rigaku Ultima X-ray diffraction spectrometer using copper Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were performed on a FEI Talos F200X American FEI instrument. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were imaged by an FEI Talos-F200S model at 300 kV equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). BET surface area and pore size measurements were done by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196 °C using Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) characterization was performed on the VISTA-MPX instrument. The sample is dissolved in a strong acid solution of HCl and HNO3, diluted, and then tested. Perform electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) testing at room temperature using the Bruker EMXplus-6/1 spectrometer. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) is used to analyze the changes in functional groups and chemical bonds in catalysts using the Nexus 670 spectrometer. The programmed temperature rise desorption (TPD) of NH3, CO2 and H2 were performed in a VDSorb-91i chemisorber equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In the TPD test, the carrier/reference gas was first pre-treated in helium (30 mL min−1) at a rate of 10 °C min−1 to 150 °C for 1 h, then lowered to the adsorption temperature of 50 °C, and after the temperature stabilization, the carrier/reference gas was switched to the adsorption gas and adsorbed at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for 1 h. Then, the carrier gas was switched to helium (30 mL min−1) and purged for 1 h. After the baseline After the baseline was stabilized, the temperature was increased to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, and the signal was recorded ten times every 1 s. In situ adsorption pyridine infrared spectroscopy (Pyridine IR) was collected on Tensor 27 spectrometer. The potassium bromide compression method was used with a resolution of 2 cm−1 and a scanning frequency of 64. Vacuum purify 20 mg of the sample at 200 °C for 1 h. Then cool to room temperature, and record the initial background spectrum at this time; Then expose the sample to pyridine vapor for 0.5 h, and then introduce He gas for 0.5 h to remove excess pyridine. To evaluate the chemical adsorption strength of pyridine, the infrared cells were heated to 90 °C, 190 °C and 290 °C (with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1) and maintained for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, collect an infrared spectrum of 1400–1700 cm−1. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed in Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. The projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials were used to describe the ionic cores and valence electrons were also considered using a plane wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV. Geometry optimizations were performed with the force convergency smaller than −0.03 eV Å−1. A 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid of the Brillouin zone is used. The adsorption energies (Eads) of ethyl levulinate and hydrogen were defined by the following equations: (1) E ads = E total – (E slab + E g) Where Etotal is the total energy of the ideal surface containing the adsorbate; Eslab is the energy of the ideal surface, and Eg is the energy of EL and H2 in the gas phase, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst preparation 2.3.1 Preparation of LaQS support Ru/LaQS was prepared by the impregnation method. LaCl3 and 8-Hydroxyquinoline-5-sulfonic Acid were used as the main materials for the synthesis of LaQS. LaCl3 (1.22 g) and 8-Hydroxyquinoline-5-sulfonic Acid (0.8 g) were fully dissolved at room temperature in 50 mL of DMF, followed by the dropwise addition of about 1 mL of ethylenediamine to the mixture, which was thoroughly stirred and transferred to a 100 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave and fully crystallized at 100 °C under autogenous pressure for 2 days. The resulting yellow crystals were filtered out and LaQS was obtained by drying after sufficient washing in ethanol. 2.3.2 Preparation of Ru/LaQS Weigh 0.4 g of LaQS obtained in the previous step and pour it into 40 mL of distilled water, stirring for 30 min to ensure that the LaQS was uniformly dispersed, which was referred to as Liquid A. Then weigh 0.5 wt%, 1 wt% and 2 wt% of the corresponding RuCl3 in 20 mL of aqueous solution, and the resulting solution is called liquid B. Liquid B was slowly dripped into liquid A and stirred for 4 h. Then 20 mL of NaBH4 solution with a concentration of 0.5 mol L−1 was slowly dripped into the mixture and stirred for another 4 h. Finally, the solution was filtered to obtain a solid and then dried sufficiently to obtain Ru0.5/LaQS, Ru1/LaQS and Ru2/LaQS catalysts. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The EL hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave having a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 1 mmol EL, 50 mg of catalyst and 8 mL of isopropanol were loaded into the reactor. The reactor was purged three times with H2 and then pressurized to 2 MPa. The reaction temperature and reaction time were set and magnetic stirring was maintained at a rate of 800 rpm throughout the reaction. At the end of the reaction the filtrate was removed with a filter membrane after cooling to room temperature. The used catalyst was washed three times with ethanol and then extracted and dried, and continued to be used for subsequent catalyst cycling experiments. The liquid phase reactants were identified using GC-MS (GCMS-QP2010 SE, Shimadzu) and the reaction samples were analyzed by GC (GC- 7890 A, Agilent). The conversion of EL and selectivity of the products were calculated as follows: (2) Conversion % = Mole of EL converted Mole of EL loaded × 100 % (3) Selectivity % = Mole of GVL produced Mole of product produced × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Interaction between the LaQS support and ultrafine Ru nanoparticles 3.1.1 LaQS anchored ultrafine Ru nanoparticles Fig. 1a shows that based on the previous work, a La-MOF (LaQS) with high stability and specific surface area was synthesized[47]. Rux/LaQS materials loaded with different contents of ultrafine Ru NPs (0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 2 wt%) were prepared by impregnation method with LaQS as support, where x is the theoretical loading of Ru. The actual metal loading of Ru/LaQS determined by ICP were 0.29 wt%, 0.72 wt% and 1.60 wt%, respectively (Table S1). Based on the analysis of the TEM of Ru/LaQS with different loading (Fig. 1b-d), the results showed that when the Ru loading was 0.5 wt%, it was difficult to clearly observe the presence of ultrafine Ru NPs due to the low content. When the loading amount of Ru is 1 wt%, ultrafine Ru NPs can be seen uniformly dispersed on LaQS. And the average particle size is slightly increased from 1.51 nm of 0.5 wt% to 1.53 nm of 1 wt%. When the loading of Ru increased to 2 wt%, the number of ultrafine Ru NPs increased significantly, but the average particle size was only 1.60 nm. This shows that the catalyst still has high dispersibility even when the loading is 2 wt%. The reasons for the uniform distribution of ultrafine Ru NPs on LaQS support may be as follows: On the one hand, LaQS support is lamellar structure (Fig. 1e), which provides more open adsorption sites for supporting metal Ru. On the other hand, there are abundant coniugated π bonds of quinoline ring on the surface of LaQS support, which can interact with metal Ru. This can effectively avoid Ru metal agglomeration. In addition, Fig. 1f clearly shows the lattice stripes of metal Ru, and the detected lattice spacing is 0.158 nm, corresponding to the 102 crystal plane of single crystal Ru (PDF#89–3942). According to the EDS element map of Ru2/LaQS (Fig. 1i), C, N, O, S, La and Ru are uniformly distributed in the structure. Moreover, the elements are highly coincident, which also proves the uniform dispersion of Ru on LaQS support. The XRD of LaQS support and Ru/LaQS with different Ru loading is shown in Fig. 1g. The XRD diffraction peaks of Ru/LaQS and LaQS support are basically the same, which indicates that the structure of LaQS remains stable after loading ultrafine Ru NPs. Immersion treatment of LaQS support in different NaBH4 concentrations confirms the structural stability of LaQS during NaBH4 treatment(Figure S1). Meanwhile, it is difficult to observe the XRD diffraction peak of ultrafine Ru NPs in Ru/LaQS. This may be because the Ru loading is less and the dispersion is even. The structures of LaQS and Ru2/LaQS were tested by N2 physical adsorption/desorption. As shown in Fig. 1h, the sample is a typical type IV adsorption-desorption isotherm, which indicates that the sample has the structure of micro-mesoporous coexistence. Moreover, the Langmuir specific surface area of LaQS is as high as 843.37 m2 g−1, which can make the ultrafine Ru NPs disperse more evenly. 3.1.2 Electronic effects of support and metal NPs LaQS and Ru/LaQS with different loading were analyzed by infrared spectrum ( Fig. 2a). Compared with the CC stretching vibration (1654 cm−1) of quinoline ring in LaQS, the absorption peak of Ru/LaQS gradually disappears. The possible reason is that the coniugated π bonds on quinoline ring in LaQS interacts with ultrafine Ru NPs. The XPS spectra of N 1 s[47,48] and C 1 s[49,50] of Ru/LaQS with different loads can also support this inference (Fig. 2b). Fig. 3c shows XPS spectra of N 1 s on Ru/LaQS with different Ru loading. Compared with the 398.87 eV of LaQS, the binding energy of N in Ru0.5/LaQS, Ru1/LaQS and Ru2/LaQS increased to 399.08, 399.16 and 399.28 eV, respectively. This proves that electrons move from N on LaQS support to Ru, which indicates the interaction between Ru NPs and CN in the quinoline ring on LaQS. With the increase of Ru loading in Ru/LaQS, the binding energy of N 1 s increases. This shows that the more electrons are transferred from N of LaQS support to Ru. Because XPS analysis needs to be corrected by C peak, it is impossible to determine the interaction between CC and ultrafine Ru NPs by C peak shift of different loading (Fig. 2b). However, with the increasing Ru loading, the relative content of CC bond in Fig. 2b decreased from 73.21% in LaQS to 42.42% in Ru2/LaQS (Table S2). Moreover, with the increase of Ru loading, the area of C peak also decreases. This shows that the increase of Ru content leads to the decrease of CC bond content. This is consistent with the results of IR spectra. This further proves the interaction between Ru NPs and CC in the quinoline ring on LaQS. It is inferred that the electrons on the CC bond move to the ultrafine Ru NPs, which leads to the decrease of the electron cloud density. In addition, we also analyzed the XPS spectra of O1s and La 3d with different loads (Figure S4), and there was no significant change in binding energy. This indicates that Ru NPs mainly interacts with the conjugated π bonds (CN and CC) of the quinoline ring on the LaQS support. Therefore, the interaction between support and metal leads to the ultrafine Ru NPs in Ru/LaQS being only 1.60 nm. The interaction between the LaQS support and the ultrafine Ru NPs not only helps its stabilization and dispersion, but also affects the electron density of Ru0. Fig. 2d shows the XPS spectra of Ru 3p on Ru/LaQS with different Ru loading[51]. The peaks at 464 eV and 486 eV are attributed to Ru0, while the peaks at 467 eV and 489 eV belong to Ru3+. Based on the spectra of O 1 s and Cl 3p, we conclude that Ru3+ exists in the form of RuCl3 on LaQS(Figure S4-S5). Compared with the 464.45 eV of Ru in Ru0.5/LaQS, the binding energy of Ru1/LaQS moves to 463.96 eV, while that of Ru2/LaQS moves to 463.65 eV. The binding energy of Ru0 shifted to the lower direction by 0.49 eV and 0.8 eV, respectively, which proves the increase of electron density of Ru0 in Ru/LaQS. And as the Ru loading in Ru/LaQS is larger, the electron density transferred from the LaQS supporter to Ru0 is larger. Therefore, Ru loading can modulate the electronic effect of LaQS support with ultrafine Ru NPs. That is, the increase of Ru loading not only increased the electron density of Ru0, but also raised the content of Ru0 and Ru3+ (Table S3). 3.2 Ru0-Ru3+ synergistic catalysis of EL 3.2.1 Ru0 with high electron density promotes catalytic performance Fig. 3a shows the comparison of catalytic performance of different catalysts in EL hydrogenation under the same reaction conditions of 100 °C and 6 h. The results showed that GVL was not detected without catalyst. When the reaction was catalyzed by LaQS support, only 10.4% conversion and 28.5% selectivity were obtained. This shows that LaQS can catalyze the reaction with acid-base synergy[47], but its catalytic performance is very low due to the weak acidic sites. When Ru2/LaQS was used as catalyst, the conversion of EL and the selectivity of GVL reached 99.9%. The commercial catalyst Ru/C has only 71.9% conversion and 78.7% selectivity. XPS results show that the acid site Ru3+ in Ru/C is only 9.58%, which may lead to lower catalytic performance than Ru2/LaQS. When Ru2/ZIF-8 was used as the control catalyst, only 44.0% conversion and 47.9% selectivity were obtained. From the TEM of Ru2/ZIF-8 (Fig. 3c), it can be found that the metal nano-size of Ru2/ZIF-8 is much higher than that of Ru2/LaQS under the same metal loading. Meanwhile, the XPS of Ru 3p in the catalyst prepared with ZIF-8 and LaQS as support was compared (Fig. 3d). Compared with 464.16 and 464.02 eV of Ru2/ZIF-8 and Ru/C, the Ru binding energy of Ru2/LaQS is reduced to 463.65 eV. It shows that higher electron density is produced on Ru0 in Ru2/LaQS, which plays a key role in promoting the high activity of catalytic reaction. By comparing the reported Ru-based catalysts, only Ru2/LaQS can achieve 99.9% selectivity for GVL under mild reaction conditions (Table S4). In order to analyze the H2 adsorption capacity of the catalyst, H2-TPD (Fig. 3b) curves of Ru/LaQS with different loadings were studied. Compared with the loading of 0.5 wt% and 1 wt%, the H2 desorption peak area of 2 wt% Ru2/LaQS is greatly increased. This is because when the loading of Ru increases, the electron density of Ru in the catalyst increases and the adsorption capacity for H2 increases. Moreover, the desorption peak of Ru2/LaQS at 210 °C showed an obvious tendency to shift to the direction of temperature increase. It shows that there is a stronger interaction between metal Ru and LaQS support in Ru2/LaQS catalyst with higher Ru loading. Therefore, the main reason why Ru2/LaQS has high catalytic activity is its small size and high electron density of Ru0. On the one hand, Ru2/LaQS has a high Langmuir specific surface area (533.87 m2 g−1) and an ultra-small ultrafine Ru NPs size of 1.60 nm, which will increase the active site density. On the other hand, increasing Ru loading leads to higher electron density of Ru0 in Ru2/LaQS. This improves the feedback from Ru to H-H antibonding orbitals and reduces the activation energy of hydrogen adsorption. This is helpful to improve the activation ability of H2. In addition, the micro-mesoporous pores of Ru2/LaQS provide great convenience for the transport of reactants and products, and the reactive molecules are more likely to contact with active sites. This is also helpful to improve the activity of Ru2/LaQS catalyst. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were used to corroborate the inference that ultrafine Ru nanoparticles are active sites for hydrogenation. Fig. 3e-f are the activation models of H2 for ultrafine Ru NPs alone and Ru NPs in Ru/LaQS, respectively. Compared with the bond length between two hydrogen atoms in free H2 (0.751 Å), the bond length of ultrafine Ru NPs after adsorption increased to 0.886 Å. However, the bond length of Ru NPs in Ru2/LaQS increased to 0.969 Å after H2 activation. This further proves that Ru0 is a hydrogenation site, which can adsorb and activate H2 molecules well. This also shows that the interaction between metal and support in Ru2/LaQS promotes the activation of H2, which is consistent with the characterization and catalytic results. 3.2.2 Enhanced acid site Ru3+ promotes catalytic performance The influence of acid-base sites on the hydrogenation of EL was studied by the experiment of poisoning EL catalyzed by Ru2/LaQS. In Fig. 4a, when the acidic sites poisoned by KSCN are added in the reaction, the conversion and selectivity are significantly reduced from 99.9% to 0%, which shows that acidic sites must exist. When benzoic acid was added to poison the basic sites, the conversion and selectivity of 99.9% decreased to 10.9% and 79.4%, respectively. This shows that alkaline sites play an important role in promoting, which is consistent with the literature[52]. In order to further discuss the influence of acid-base sites on hydrogenation reaction, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD tests were carried out. The alkaline sites were analyzed by CO2-TPD (Figure S3), and the adsorption peaks of LaQS support at 225 °C and Ru/LaQS at 170 °C were presumed to be electron-rich N on LaQS support. Because of the interaction between the loaded ultrafine Ru NPs and electron-rich N, the electron cloud density of N decreases, which leads to the weakening of its alkalinity. However, the weak base sites near 210 °C may be metal Ru in Ru/LaQS with different loading. XPS analysis of Ru 3p shows that the increase of Ru loading leads to more electron transfer from LaQS support to ultrafine Ru NPs. This leads to the higher the electron density of Ru0, the stronger the alkalinity. The acid sites were further analyzed by NH3-TPD (Fig. 4b). It can be seen from Fig. 4b that the greater the Ru loading on LaQS, the stronger the acidity of Ru/LaQS. The NH3 desorption peak of Ru/LaQS loaded with different amounts of Ru at 90 °C may be caused by physical adsorption. The desorption peak at 150 °C may be the acidic site caused by the desorption of unsaturated La ions of DMF molecules[47]. It is worth noting that NH3-TPD has a new desorption peak at 210 °C, and the desorption peak is stronger with the increase of Ru loading. This corresponds to the Ru3+ content of Ru0.5/LaQS (13.29%) in the XPS of Ru 3p increasing to 15.93% of Ru2/LaQS (Table S3). Compared with Ru2/LaQS, the desorption peak of Ru3/LaQS at 210 °C is further increased when the addition of Ru increased to 3 wt% (Fig. 4b). Moreover, NH3-TPD of LaQS-NaBH4 did not show the medium-strong acid site, which further indicates that Ru3+ in Ru/LaQS is the new intermediate-strong Lewis acid site. Meanwhile, it also shows that the loading of Ru on LaQS support can regulate the intermediate-strong acid sites of Ru/LaQS. Therefore, Ru2/LaQS with higher Ru loading has higher acid strength, which is helpful to improve the catalyst's ability to activate CO on EL[53]. Characterization using in situ CO diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (in situ CO DRIFT-IR) revealed that two CO strong absorption bands were detected at the vicinity of 2171 and 2119 cm−1 for the reduced Ru/LaQS catalysts (Fig. 4c), which corresponds to the linear adsorption of CO onto Ru ions[54,55]. In contrast, there is no CO absorption band in the range of 1800–2100 cm−1, indicating that Ru0 is not adsorbed on CO. This further suggests that Ru3+ is the active site for the activation of EL, which is consistent with the XPS and NH3-TPD analyses.The spectral analysis of the pyridine IR of Ru2/LaQS with LaQS at 90 °C is presented in Fig. 4d. The two strong absorption peaks at 1612 cm−1 and 1448 cm−1 are attributed to Lewis acid sites, which are caused by pyridine adsorption on Ru3+. While the absorption peak at 1580 cm−1 may be caused by unsaturated La3+. Brönsted acid site is represented near 1540 cm−1, and the weak absorption peak at 1490 cm−1 corresponds to the co-adsorption of pyridine on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites[56]. Meanwhile, an interesting phenomenon was found that the Lewis acid to Brönsted acid ratio (L/B) was much larger for Ru2/LaQS (9.840: 5.622) as compared to that in LaQS. And this phenomenon was still present at the elevated desorption temperatures of 190 °C (6.355: 4.369) and 290 °C (3.474: 2.710) (Table S5). This proves that the interaction of ultrafine Ru NPs with the support produces a higher proportion of medium-strong Lewis acid sites, which is consistent with the results of NH3-TPD. It was also shown that the higher GVL yields from LA hydrogenation over Zr-Beta zeolite catalysts are attributed to the presence of Lewis acid sites[57]. In order to investigate the activation effect on EL after metal loading, DFT theoretical calculations were carried out for the adsorption of EL on alone ultrafine Ru NPs, Ru NPs and La3+ sites in Ru2/LaQS, respectively ( Fig. 5a-c). From the poisoning experiments of EL hydrogenation, it is known that the acidic sites are poisoned by KSCN and the EL conversion is 0 (Fig. 4a). And the Lewis acidic sites on the catalyst surface originated from Ru3+ in ultrafine Ru NPs and La3+ in LaQS. This indicates that EL adsorption at Ru3+ or La3+ is activated. As can be seen from the Fig. 5a-c, the adsorption energy of Ru3+ in Ru/LaQS for EL (-1.419 eV) is much larger than that of La3+ (-0.654 eV), which represents that the CO of EL is mainly activated on Ru3+ in Ru/LaQS[58]. Meanwhile, comparing the bond length of CO on free EL (1.222 Å), the bond lengths of Ru3+ and La3+ adsorbed CO in Ru2/LaQS grew to 1.256 Å and 1.227 Å, respectively, which further suggests that the EL adsorbed at Ru3+ in Ru/LaQS. Meanwhile, in combination with NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 4b), the Lewis acidic site Ru3+ with medium-strong acidic strength was the main active site for the activation of EL. In addition, the commercial catalyst Ru/C had high EL conversion (71.9%) and GVL selectivity (78.7%) under the same conditions, but was lower than that of Ru2/LaQS (99.9%) (Fig. 3a). The possible reason is that Ru/C is only 9.58% compared to Ru3+ content of Ru2/LaQS (15.93%). Meanwhile, compared with 1.254 Å for the adsorption of CO bond of EL at ultrafine Ru NPs (Fig. 5a), CO bond length by Ru3+ in Ru2/LaQS increases to 1.256 Å (Fig. 5b). This shows that the interaction between LaQS and ultrafine Ru NPs promotes the activation of EL at Ru3+ on Ru2/LaQS. According to the literature, Lewis acid have a major role in the molecular dealcoholization reaction in EL hydrogenation[52,59]. According to XPS and NH3-TPD analyses, Ru2/LaQS with higher Ru loading has higher acid strength, which contributes to the intramolecular dealcoholization process of the intermediate 4-hydroxyvalerate (4-HPE). To further investigate the role of acidic sites in the dealcoholization process of the intermediate, DFT theoretical calculations were made for the adsorption of 4-HPE at ultrafine Ru NPs and La3+ on Ru/LaQS, and La3+ on LaQS, respectively. Relative to the adsorption energy of La3+ on Ru/LaQS for C-O in 4-HPE (-0.460 eV), the adsorption energy of Ru3+ on Ru/LaQS is increased to −1.217 eV, which indicates that the intermediate 4-HPE is also mainly adsorbed on Ru3+ of Ru/LaQS. This is consistent with the analysis results of EL adsorption on Ru3+ of Ru/LaQS. Moreover, the adsorption energy of Ru3+ and La3+ on Ru/LaQS for C-O in 4-HPE (-1.217 eV and −0.460 eV) were also larger than that of La3+ on LaQS (-0.446 eV), which suggests that the interaction between LaQS and ultrafine Ru NPs in Ru/LaQS promotes the adsorption of 4-HPE. Meanwhile, compared with the C-O bond length on free 4-HPE (1.441 Å), the C-O bond length adsorbed at Ru3+ on Ru/LaQS increased to 1.489 Å. However, the bond length of C-O in 4-HPE adsorbed by La3+ on Ru/LaQS is only 1.434 Å. This further shows that Ru3+ on Ru/LaQS has a stronger effect on 4-HPE, which is more beneficial to the next dealcoholization reaction. Based on the above analysis, the reaction mechanism of catalytic hydrogenation of EL by Ru2/LaQS was hypothesized ( Fig. 6d). The hydrogenation reaction of EL undergoes EL hydrogenation to generate the intermediate 4-HPE and intramolecular dealcoholization of 4-HPE to generate GVL, which requires bifunctional catalysts possessing both the hydrogenation active site and the Lewis acidic site. Experimental results and DFT calculations indicate that ultrafine Ru NPs (1.60 nm) on the LaQS surface are the key sites for the conversion of EL to GVL. Characterization results demonstrated that the strong metal-support effect in Ru2/LaQS resulted in the increase of Ru loading not only increased the electron density and content of Ru0, but also the content of Ru3+ (Table S3). First, H2 molecules adsorbed on the Ru0 active sites with high-electron-density were activated to hydrogen atoms. Meanwhile, NH3-TPD and DFT demonstrated that the Ru3+ sites can effectively adsorb CO in EL, which is also consistent with literature reports[58]. Then, the activated H atoms attack the CO on the adjacent activated EL to generate the intermediate 4-HPE. -O-H of 4-HPE adsorbs on the Ru3+ and basic sites, respectively. Lewis acidic sites play a key role in the generation of GVL from 4-HPE[52,59]. The medium-strong Lewis acidic sites on the catalyst surface are mainly derived from Ru3+ in Ru/LaQS. As the increase of Ru loading raises the content of medium-strong acid Ru3+, the intramolecular ester exchange reaction on the acidic sites of the catalyst to remove ethanol can easily convert 4-HPE to GVL without any other by-products. Finally, the generated GVL was desorbed from the catalyst surface, and the catalytically active sites were directly recycled. It can be seen that the synergistic effect of Ru0-Ru3+ promotes the adsorption of reactants and the formation of the intermediate 4-HPE, and significantly accelerates the intramolecular dehydrogenation of 4-HPE to GVL via intramolecular nucleophilic addition. 3.2.3 The interaction between the support and Ru NPs improves the stability As an important element in the examination of catalyst performance, the cycling test of Ru2/LaQS in the EL selective hydrogenation was investigated. After the EL hydrogenation was completed, the catalyst was allowed to dry and then repeated for EL hydrogenation at a reduced reaction temperature (90 °C). After three cycle reactions, the EL conversion of and GVL selectivity remained unchanged, indicating the excellent stability of the catalyst ( Fig. 7a). The used Ru2/LaQS catalyst was shown to be similar to the fresh catalyst by XRD analysis (Fig. 7b). XPS analysis of fresh and used Ru2/LaQS catalysts showed that the Ru0 and Ru3+ content of the ultrafine Ru NPs were essentially unchanged (Fig. 7d). According to TEM, it can be seen that the Ru NPs did not undergo significant clustering (Fig. 7c). Meanwhile, Ru was not observed within the detection limit of ICP-OES, indicating that no loss of Ru occurred during the reaction. This suggests that the reaction is a non-homogeneous catalytic process and further demonstrates the stability of Ru2/LaQS. The high stability of Ru2/LaQS during the cycle is mainly attributed to the coordination between ultrafine Ru NPs and the quinoline ring on LaQS support through coniugated π bonds, which anchors ultrafine Ru NPs to prevent agglomeration and metal loss. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Ru/LaQS catalyst with LaQS supported ultrafine Ru NPs is a highly active and stable bifunctional catalyst with hydrogenation center and Lewis acid, which is used for EL to GVL at low temperature. The experimental results and theoretical calculations show that the synergistic effect between the hydrogenation site Ru0 and Lewis acid site Ru3+ on Ru/LaQS has a decisive role in EL conversion and product selectivity. The metal-support effect in Ru2/LaQS results in a ultrafine Ru NPs size of only 1.60 nm. Meanwhile, the increase of Ru loading not only increases the electron density of Ru0, but also increases the content of Ru0 and Ru3+. The synergistic interaction of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs facilitated the conversion of H2 and EL, and the intramolecular dealcoholization of the intermediate to GVL, which significantly increased the yield of GVL (99.9%). The electron-rich Ru0 active site caused by the electron transfer from LaQS to Ru0 effectively adsorbed and activated H2 molecules. The Lewis acidic site Ru3+, which was increased in content, not only effectively adsorbed and activated the CO group in EL, but also was the key site for the intramolecular dehydrogenation of the intermediate 4-HPE to GVL. In addition, the strong interaction between the Ru metal and LaQS support prevented the agglomeration and loss of ultrafine Ru NPs during cycling. The bifunctional modulation strategy through metal-acidic sites provide a reference for the use of MOFs-based catalysts for biomass conversion. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of bifunctional catalysts is very important for the hydrogenation of biomass to advanced biofuels, but its efficient regulation is difficult. In this work, a tunable bifunctional Ru/LaQS catalyst with Lewis acid and metal hydrogenation sites was prepared by stable MOFs (LaQS) supported ultrafine Ru nanoparticles (NPs). When the optimal Ru2/LaQS catalyst catalyzed bio-based ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL), the EL conversion and GVL selectivity reached 99.9% under mild conditions of 100 °C. The excellent catalytic performance is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs with only 1.60 nm generated by metal-support interaction, which is proved by experimental characterization and theoretical calculation. Moreover, the electron density of hydrogenation active site Ru0 and the content of acidic site Ru3+ can be modulated by Ru loading. Among them, the activation of H2 was promoted by the high electron density of Ru0 generated through metal-support electronic interactions. The enhanced medium-strong acidic site Ru3+ not only improved the activation of EL, but also promoted the intramolecular dealcoholization of the intermediate to GVL. The synergistic catalytic mechanism of Ru0-Ru3+ on ultrafine Ru NPs was speculated. The excellent stability was mainly attributed to the metal-support interaction stabilizing the ultrafine Ru NPs, which prevents the agglomeration and loss of Ru NPs during cycling. This work provides an in-depth understanding of the bifunctional catalytic mechanism, which is of guiding significance for the design and preparation of MOFs-based catalysts for biomass hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic catalysis of Ru0-Ru3+ in MOF supported ultrafine Ru nanoparticles catalyst promotes ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone
